title: 115_hr2831
content: The "Maritime Security Coordination Improvement Act" requires the Secretary to submit updates on the strategic plan for enhancing international supply chain security every three years. Additionally, it includes provisions for the Container Security Initiative. SEC. 3 amends section 205 of the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006, changing deadlines and redesignating subparagraphs. SEC. 4 addresses cybersecurity at ports. The amendments focus on enhancing cybersecurity in maritime security activities by facilitating information sharing on cybersecurity risks and incidents, conducting vulnerability assessments, and updating security plans at ports. The amendments aim to improve cybersecurity in maritime security by including cybersecurity measures in security plans at ports and addressing prevention, management, and response to cybersecurity risks and incidents. SEC. 5. Facility inspection intervals are amended to verify the effectiveness of security plans annually and as needed. SEC. 6. Recognition of other countries' trusted shipper programs is addressed in the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006. SEC. 6. RECOGNITION OF OTHER COUNTRIES' TRUSTED SHIPPER PROGRAMS. Amendment to Section 218 of the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 requires notification and consultation before signing arrangements with foreign governments for mutual recognition of supply chain security practices. The foreign government's supply chain security program must provide comparable security as C-TPAT. SEC. 7. UPDATES OF MARITIME OPERATIONS COORDINATION PLAN. Subtitle C of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new section for updates of the Maritime Operations Coordination Plan. The Secretary must submit a maritime operations coordination plan every 180 days to specific committees, updating the plan released in July 2011. The plan includes coordination of maritime operations, joint domain awareness efforts, information sharing, and intelligence integration with various stakeholders for maritime security. The Secretary must maintain effective information sharing and intelligence integration with Federal, State, and local officials, as well as the private sector, regarding maritime security threats. Cooperation and coordination with other government departments and agencies, as well as State and local agencies, are essential for supporting maritime homeland security missions. Work is conducted within the framework of national and Department maritime security strategic guidance. SEC. 434 requires updates to the maritime operations coordination plan. SEC. 8 focuses on evaluating the Coast Guard's deployable specialized forces. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to specific committees on the state of the Coast Guard's Deployable Specialized Forces, including cost analysis, personnel numbers, units, operations conducted, and operations requested. The report must include the total number of operations conducted, operations requested by various entities, and an examination of alternative distributions of Deployable Specialized Forces, such as combining counterdrug operations under one command and distributing counter-terrorism capabilities to DSFs in major U.S. ports. The report must include the total number of operations conducted, operations requested by various entities, and an examination of alternative distributions of Deployable Specialized Forces, such as combining counterdrug operations under one command and distributing counter-terrorism capabilities to DSFs in major U.S. ports. A Deployable Specialized Force is a Coast Guard unit for quick reaction in handling counter-drug, counter-terrorism, and anti-terrorism operations or other maritime threats to the United States. SEC. 9. COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS OF CO-LOCATING DHS ASSETS. The Secretary of Homeland Security shall conduct a cost-benefit analysis for co-locating aviation and maritime assets of the Office of Air and Marine Operations with other Department of Homeland Security agencies within 45 miles. Factors considered include enhanced cooperation, shared maintenance and logistics facilities, joint use of infrastructure, and operational costs. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a cost-benefit analysis for co-locating aviation and maritime assets within 45 miles, considering factors like joint use of infrastructure, operational costs, and potential moving and acquisition costs. A report summarizing the analysis results and planned actions will be submitted to relevant committees within one year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 10 repeals Sections 70107A and 70116 of title 46, United States Code. SEC. 11 includes conforming and clerical amendments. Sections of the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 are being amended, including redesignating and striking certain sections. Sections of the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 are being amended, including redesignating and striking certain sections such as section 233, 235, 236, 701, and 708. The table of contents is also being amended to reflect these changes. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is being amended to include new sections such as random searches of containers, work stoppages, threat assessment screening of port truck drivers, Border Patrol unit for US Virgin Islands, and Center of Excellence for Maritime Domain Awareness. The Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006 is being amended to include new sections related to supply chain security cooperation, disclosures regarding homeland security grants, trucking security, air and marine operations, phaseout of vessels supporting oil and gas development, Coast Guard property, methamphetamine regulations, and protection of health and safety during disasters. Additionally, amendments are made to Title 46 regarding the analysis for chapter 701.
